children.definition: Complete prohibition on borrower mergers/consolidations. Maximum protection of borrower entity integrity.
children.name: Merger Prohibition

children.definition: No Event of Default before or after giving effect to merger. Pro forma compliance required. Standard condition in all permitted merger formulations.
children.name: No Default Condition
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 3 Item 10; Review Template Row 148 (Conditions Annex)

children.definition: Successor entity must be organized under laws of a U.S. jurisdiction. Ensures continued legal framework for enforcement.
children.name: US Entity Requirement

children.definition: Successor must formally assume all borrower obligations under the credit agreement through supplemental indenture or joinder. 87.1% when merger permitted.
children.name: Assumption of Obligations

children.definition: Surviving entity must satisfy financial covenants on pro forma basis after giving effect to the merger and any related transactions. Leverage ratio tested most commonly.
children.name: Pro Forma Compliance
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 48 (Pro Forma Financial Statements)

children.definition: Mergers permitted via investment basket capacity or asset sale reinvestment. Leverage governor applies. Cross-references investment and disposition covenants.
children.name: Investment Covenant Pathway

children.definition: Merger permitted subject to safeguards: no EoD, US entity requirement, assumption of obligations.
children.name: Conditional Permission

children.definition: Whether guarantor subsidiaries may merge with each other or with borrower. Typically more permissive than borrower merger — no net reduction in guarantee coverage if survivor is a loan party.
children.name: Guarantor Merger Permission

children.definition: Whether borrower can merge or consolidate with another entity. 55.9% prohibit; 44.1% permit with conditions. Prevents borrower from escaping covenant obligations through corporate reorganization.
children.name: Merger Covenant

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Dollar baskets include EBITDA/Total Assets grower; reclassification of baskets; exclude simultaneous fixed-amount incurrences from ratio tests; covenants run from Borrower/restricted subs down with passive holdco only for Holdings
key_negotiation_axes: grower_baskets: not_permitted vs ebitda_based vs total_assets_based

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 73 (Covenant); DLS Preferred Row 74 (Cushion/Covenant Levels); DLS Preferred Row 89 (Other Covenant Considerations)

children.definition: Prohibition on sale of substantially all assets of borrower and subsidiaries taken as a whole. 'Substantially all' undefined in most agreements — typically 75-90% of total assets by value.
children.name: Substantially All Assets Test

children.definition: Individual asset sales governed by disposition covenant; substantially-all test governs aggregate effect. Must read both provisions together for complete picture.
children.name: Disposition Covenant Cross-Reference

children.definition: Structural protection restricting sale of substantially all assets outside the disposition covenant. Prevents borrower circumvention of the merger covenant through piecemeal asset sales that achieve the same economic effect. In the credit protection framework, this is a STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY control that prevents dissolution of the credit group's asset base through transactions that individually pass disposition basket tests but collectively destroy the collateral estate.
children.name: Asset Sale Restrictions

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Dollar baskets include EBITDA/Total Assets grower; reclassification of baskets; exclude simultaneous fixed-amount incurrences from ratio tests; covenants run from Borrower/restricted subs down with passive holdco only for Holdings
key_negotiation_axes: grower_baskets: not_permitted vs ebitda_based vs total_assets_based

children.definition: Absolute prohibition on borrower voluntarily dissolving, liquidating, or winding up its affairs. Universal protection — no exceptions or carveouts.
children.name: Borrower Dissolution Prohibition

children.definition: Subsidiaries may dissolve if: (1) assets transferred to another loan party, (2) no material assets at time of dissolution, (3) dissolution is in best interest of borrower. More permissive than borrower restriction.
children.name: Subsidiary Dissolution Exceptions

children.definition: Prohibition on voluntary dissolution, liquidation, or winding up of borrower and material subsidiaries. Prevents borrower from terminating its legal existence and escaping obligations.
children.name: Dissolution Restrictions

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Dollar baskets include EBITDA/Total Assets grower; reclassification of baskets; exclude simultaneous fixed-amount incurrences from ratio tests; covenants run from Borrower/restricted subs down with passive holdco only for Holdings
key_negotiation_axes: grower_baskets: not_permitted vs ebitda_based vs total_assets_based

children.definition: Conditions for designating a subsidiary as unrestricted: no Event of Default, investment capacity available, pro forma financial covenant compliance. J.Crew blocks IP-holding subs.

market_benchmarks.pctc_cmm_lmm: deals may be Closing Total Leverage.
market_benchmarks.pctc_umm_bsl: may limit tobktcy/payment EOD; . Otherwise would be pro forma compliance with Financial Covenant (if there is one) and in more conservative CMM/LMM deals may be Closing Total Leverage.; Often absent; transactions may seek overall cap on assets andEbitda of Unrestricted Subs in the 5-10% range.

children.name: Designation Conditions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 89; Review Template Row 148 (Conditions Annex)

children.definition: Right to redesignate unrestricted subsidiary back to restricted status. Requires: no EoD, pro forma compliance, debt of redesignated sub must be permitted. Creates flexibility for tax planning.
children.name: Redesignation Rights

children.definition: Designation treated as investment equal to FMV of the subsidiary. Must be made under an available investment basket (general, permitted acquisition, or RP capacity).
children.name: Investment Capacity Requirement

children.definition: Whether unrestricted subs can incur debt that would be prohibited for restricted subs or cross-default to the credit facility. Anti-cross-default provisions prevent contagion.
children.name: Cross-Debt Restrictions

children.definition: Cannot designate a subsidiary representing a principal operating business as unrestricted. Prevents value stripping of core enterprise via designation mechanics.
children.name: Principal Subsidiary Exclusion

children.definition: Governance over designation of subsidiaries as unrestricted, exempting them from covenant compliance and removing them from the restricted group. Primary LME attack vector for value extraction.
children.name: Unrestricted Subsidiaries

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Designation/re-designation permitted subject to: no EoD, pro forma compliance with closing-date leverage ratios (or financial covenant), no recourse to Loan Parties, no ownership of Borrower stock/debt, restricted sub under other debt docs, asset/EBITDA caps, financial statement reconciliation
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: No ability to designate unrestricted subsidiaries

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Unrestricted Subsidiary Stock

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 92 (Unrestricted Subsidiaries); Review Template Row 67 (Unrestricted Subsidiaries - generally); Review Template Row 68 (Negative Covenants – Unrestricted Subsidiaries – Envision); Review Template Row 107 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Unrestricted Subsidiary Stock)

children.definition: 2.5% of consolidated total assets individually. Most common materiality test.
children.name: Asset-Based Test

children.definition: Revenue test for material subsidiary designation: subsidiaries exceeding a specified percentage (typically 2.5%) of consolidated revenues individually are classified as material and subject to enhanced reporting, guarantee, and covenant requirements.
children.name: Revenue-Based Test

children.definition: 2.5% of consolidated EBITDA individually. Most sophisticated test, correlates with earning power rather than balance sheet value.
children.name: EBITDA-Based Test

children.definition: 5% aggregate standard. Cumulative ceiling prevents aggregate exclusion of material value through multiple individually-immaterial subs.
children.name: Aggregate Threshold

children.definition: Prevents asset-light but IP-critical subs from falling below materiality thresholds.
children.name: IP Holder Override

children.definition: Financial thresholds for guarantee and collateral requirements. 85.5% coverage. Determines which entities must be loan parties.
children.name: Material Subsidiaries

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Dollar baskets include EBITDA/Total Assets grower; reclassification of baskets; exclude simultaneous fixed-amount incurrences from ratio tests; covenants run from Borrower/restricted subs down with passive holdco only for Holdings
key_negotiation_axes: grower_baskets: not_permitted vs ebitda_based vs total_assets_based

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 92 (Unrestricted Subsidiaries); Review Template Row 39 (Collateral and Guarantors); Review Template Row 51 (Reps and Warranties)

children.definition: Holdco may only own equity of borrower and engage in limited permitted activities (tax compliance, regulatory filings, corporate governance). No active business conduct.
children.name: Standard Restriction

children.definition: Limited holdco debt permitted for intercompany loans to borrower that are on-lent and subordinated. Enables tax-efficient capital structure.
children.name: Debt Incurrence Exception

children.definition: Some deals treat passive holdco violation as Event of Default rather than standalone negative covenant. Elevated consequences for breach.
children.name: EoD If Violated

children.definition: KCT cat4.5 requires the protective mechanism 'holdco incurrence equivalence test (could have been incurred at opco)' but it is not adequately represented in the ontology.
children.name: Holdco Incurrence Equivalence Test

children.definition: Restricts holding company to passive ownership, preventing Holdings from conducting business or incurring obligations that could compete with or subordinate the credit facility claims. DLS Preferred row 88 includes 'Passive holding company covenant for Holdings' as a standard negative covenant, and row 89 (Other Covenant Considerations) specifies that 'Covenants run from Borrower and restricted subs down, with a passive holding company covenant only, with respect to Holdings.' This ensures Holdings exists solely to own the borrower's equity and does not create independent obligations that could structurally priority over the credit facility.
children.name: Passive Holdco Covenant

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Dollar baskets include EBITDA/Total Assets grower; reclassification of baskets; exclude simultaneous fixed-amount incurrences from ratio tests; covenants run from Borrower/restricted subs down with passive holdco only for Holdings
key_negotiation_axes: grower_baskets: not_permitted vs ebitda_based vs total_assets_based

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Non-guarantor/foreign subsidiary debt
Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Unrestricted Subsidiary Stock

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 88 (passive holdco covenant in Other Negative Covenants); DLS Preferred row 89 (covenants run from Borrower down, passive holdco only for Holdings)

children.definition: Must remain in same or related/similar/ancillary business as conducted at closing.
children.name: Standard Restriction

children.definition: Broadened language: 'similar, incidental, ancillary, supportive, synergistic or reasonably related.' 6.5% of deals. Greater operational flexibility.
children.name: Flexible Formulation

children.definition: Restriction on entering new lines of business. DLS Preferred row 82 (Permitted Acquisitions) condition (ii) requires that 'after giving effect thereto, the Borrower is in compliance with the permitted lines of business covenant.' DLS Preferred row 88 includes 'Changes in line of business' as a standard negative covenant. This ensures the borrower remains in the business that lenders underwrote, preventing diversification into higher-risk or unfamiliar industries that could change the credit risk profile.
children.name: Line of Business Restriction

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Dollar baskets include EBITDA/Total Assets grower; reclassification of baskets; exclude simultaneous fixed-amount incurrences from ratio tests; covenants run from Borrower/restricted subs down with passive holdco only for Holdings
key_negotiation_axes: grower_baskets: not_permitted vs ebitda_based vs total_assets_based

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 82 condition (ii) (line of business compliance for acquisitions); DLS Preferred row 88 (changes in line of business as negative covenant)

children.definition: Covenant prohibiting the borrower from changing its fiscal year-end without lender consent. A fiscal year change would alter the measurement periods for financial covenant testing, excess cash flow calculations, and reporting obligations, potentially creating misalignment between the credit agreement's testing schedule and the borrower's actual financial reporting cycle.
children.name: Prohibition

children.definition: Fiscal year changes required by GAAP or regulatory changes permitted without consent. Prevents covenant breach from mandatory accounting standard transitions.
children.name: Accounting Changes Exception

children.definition: Restrictions on changes to the fiscal year end. Ensures financial reporting cadence matches covenant testing periods and compliance certificate delivery schedules.
children.name: Change of Fiscal Year

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Dollar baskets include EBITDA/Total Assets grower; reclassification of baskets; exclude simultaneous fixed-amount incurrences from ratio tests; covenants run from Borrower/restricted subs down with passive holdco only for Holdings
key_negotiation_axes: grower_baskets: not_permitted vs ebitda_based vs total_assets_based

children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 4; Review Template Row 130 (Change of Control)

children.definition: Only amendments 'materially adverse to lenders' are restricted. Borrower determines materiality in good faith. Creates subjectivity in compliance.
children.name: Materiality Qualifier

children.definition: Restriction applies only to organizational documents of loan parties (borrower + guarantors). Non-guarantor subs may freely amend their org docs.
children.name: Loan Parties Only Scope

children.definition: Restriction on amendments to organizational documents (charter, bylaws, LLC agreement) that would be materially adverse to lenders. DLS Preferred row 88 includes 'Modifications to organizational documents that are materially adverse to the lenders' as a standard negative covenant. This prevents the borrower from restructuring its governance, ownership, or distribution mechanics in ways that could undermine lender rights or structural protections embedded in the organizational documents.
children.name: Organizational Document Amendments

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Dollar baskets include EBITDA/Total Assets grower; reclassification of baskets; exclude simultaneous fixed-amount incurrences from ratio tests; covenants run from Borrower/restricted subs down with passive holdco only for Holdings
key_negotiation_axes: grower_baskets: not_permitted vs ebitda_based vs total_assets_based

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 88 (organizational document amendment restriction in Other Negative Covenants)

children.name: IP Preservation Scope
children.definition: Which intellectual property must be maintained — patents, trademarks, copyrights, trade secrets material to the business — and the standard of care required (ordinary course, commercially reasonable efforts).

children.name: Licensing Restrictions
children.definition: Limitations on licensing material IP to third parties, including prohibitions on exclusive licenses, requirements for arm's-length terms, and carve-outs for ordinary course licensing arrangements.

children.name: Enforcement Obligation
children.definition: Affirmative obligation to enforce and protect material intellectual property rights against infringement, including prosecution of infringers and maintenance of registrations and filings.

Affirmative covenant requiring the borrower and its restricted subsidiaries to maintain, protect, and defend their material intellectual property rights, including timely prosecution of patent applications, renewal of trademark registrations, and enforcement against infringement. Protects the value of IP assets that support the borrower's competitive position and enterprise value.

market_benchmarks.prevalence: medium -- more common in IP-heavy borrowers
market_benchmarks.typical_standard: maintain material IP in ordinary course

children.name: Affirmative IP maintenance covenant
Permitted Hedging Purposes
children.definition: The bona fide business purposes for which hedging is permitted — interest rate risk management, currency exposure, commodity price risk — with a blanket prohibition on speculative or trading activity.

children.name: Permitted Instrument Types
children.definition: Which derivative instruments are permitted (swaps, caps, collars, forwards) versus prohibited (options for speculative gain, credit default swaps on unrelated reference entities, leveraged derivatives).

children.name: Counterparty Requirements
children.definition: Requirements that hedging counterparties be lenders under the credit agreement or their affiliates, or meet specified credit ratings, to ensure hedge obligations benefit from the collateral package.

Negative covenant prohibiting the borrower from entering into derivative or hedging transactions for speculative purposes. DLS Preferred row 88 includes 'Speculative hedging' as a standard negative covenant. DLS Preferred row 78 affirmative covenants clause (xxii) requires 'interest rate protection' (highlighted), which is the counterpart requiring the borrower to maintain hedging for risk management. The speculative hedging prohibition ensures derivative positions serve only to mitigate business risks (interest rate, currency, commodity) rather than creating additional speculative exposure.

market_benchmarks.typical_standard: hedging for bona fide business purposes only

children.name: Prohibition on speculative hedging
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 88 (speculative hedging negative covenant); DLS Preferred row 78 clause (xxii) (highlighted: interest rate protection affirmative covenant)

children.name: Lease Payment Cap Structure
children.definition: The annual or aggregate cap on operating lease payments — expressed as a fixed dollar amount, percentage of consolidated total assets, or percentage of EBITDA — limiting off-balance-sheet leverage.

children.name: ASC 842 Treatment
children.definition: How the covenant interacts with ASC 842 lease accounting — whether the restriction applies to operating lease expense, right-of-use asset value, or lease liability — with many pre-2019 covenants becoming less relevant post-adoption.

children.name: Excluded Lease Types
children.definition: Operating leases carved out from the cap — short-term leases under 12 months, real property leases in ordinary course, leases existing at closing — which reduce the effective bite of the restriction.

Restriction limiting the borrower's aggregate operating lease obligations, typically expressed as a dollar cap on annual lease expense or total capitalized lease obligations. Constrains off-balance-sheet leverage created through operating leases that, while not classified as debt for covenant purposes, represent fixed obligations competing with debt service for operating cash flow.

market_benchmarks.typical_cap: percentage of consolidated total assets or fixed dollar

children.name: Operating lease cap/restriction
General Issuance Prohibition
children.definition: Blanket prohibition on restricted subsidiaries issuing equity to third parties, which would dilute the borrower's (and lenders') indirect claim on subsidiary assets and cash flows.

children.name: Permitted Issuances
children.definition: Exceptions allowing subsidiary equity issuance — to the borrower or wholly-owned subsidiaries, qualifying preferred equity, de minimis director qualifying shares, and issuances in connection with permitted acquisitions.

children.name: Collateral Dilution Impact
children.definition: Consequences of permitted subsidiary equity issuance on the collateral package — pledge requirements for new equity, maintenance of ownership thresholds, and adjustment of guarantee obligations.

Covenant restricting subsidiaries from issuing equity interests to third parties (other than to the borrower or a wholly-owned subsidiary). DLS Preferred row 88 includes 'Issuance of capital stock of subsidiaries' as a standard negative covenant. KCT Category 2 item 3 flags: 'Permit uncapped issuance of preferred stock at a non-guarantor restricted subsidiary that would be structurally senior to lenders or excluded from debt incurrence or covenant calculations.' Unrestricted subsidiary equity issuance to third parties can dilute the consolidated group's claim on subsidiary assets and create structural subordination.

market_benchmarks.prevalence: medium -- prevents dilution of collateral value
market_benchmarks.typical_exceptions: issuance to parent, qualifying equity, de minimis

children.name: Restriction on subsidiary equity issuance
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 88 (subsidiary equity issuance restriction in Other Negative Covenants); KCT Category 2 item 3 (uncapped preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary)

children.name: Successor Entity Conditions
children.definition: Requirements the surviving or successor entity must satisfy — US jurisdiction, assumption of all obligations, no EoD, pro forma covenant compliance — to permit a merger or consolidation without lender consent.

children.name: No Default Requirement
children.definition: Condition that no Default or Event of Default exists or would result from the fundamental change on a pro forma basis, tested both before and immediately after giving effect to the transaction.

children.name: Collateral & Guarantee Continuation
children.definition: Requirement that the collateral package and guarantee structure survive the fundamental change — successor assumes pledge obligations, no lien release without consent, security interests remain perfected.
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 2 Item 1; Learning Material: GUARANTEE AND COLLATERAL RELEASE PROVISIONS

children.name: Permitted Fundamental Changes
children.definition: Carve-outs from the merger restriction — subsidiary mergers into other loan parties, immaterial subsidiary dissolutions, and mergers where the borrower is the surviving entity — that do not require covenant compliance testing.

Covenant restricting mergers, consolidations, and fundamental structural changes. Also known as the merger covenant. Covers requirements for successor entity to assume borrower obligations, conditions on asset sales that constitute effective mergers, and dissolution restrictions.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

market_benchmarks.typical_exceptions: mergers where borrower is surviving entity and no EoD

children.name: Fundamental Changes / Mergers

definition: Provisions governing mergers, subsidiary structure, line of business, organizational integrity, and structural protections. DLS Preferred row 88 (Other Negative Covenants) enumerates: modifications to junior/subordinated debt documents materially adverse to lenders; modifications to organizational documents materially adverse to lenders; burdensome agreements, negative pledge clauses, and agreements restricting subsidiary distributions; change in accounting policies or fiscal year; passive holding company covenant for Holdings; incurrence of guarantee or contingent obligations; speculative hedging; changes in line of business; issuance of capital stock of subsidiaries; operating leases. These structural protections ensure the corporate entity that borrowed the funds maintains its organizational integrity and cannot restructure itself to the detriment of lenders.
name: Corporate Structure
definition_source: DLS Preferred row 88 (Other Negative Covenants: complete enumeration of 10 structural protection categories)
